journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Artificial neural network based modelling of performance of a beta-type Stirling engine

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Mechanical Education, Faculty of Technical Education, A.N.S Campus, Afyon Kocatepe University, Afyonkarahisar, Turkey
2Department of Automotive Engineering, Faculty of Technology, Gazi University, Beşevler, Ankara, Turkey
3Department of Manufacturing Engineering, Faculty of Technology, Düzce University, Konuralp Yerleşkesi, Düzce, Turkey
4Department of Mechanical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering and Natural Sciences, Yıldırm Beyazıt University, Ankara, Turkey
5Department of Mechanical Education, Faculty of Technical Education, Düzce University, Konuralp Yerleşkesi, Düzce, Turkey

author-notes.corresp: Suat Sarıdemir, Department of Manufacturing Engineering, Faculty of Technology, Düzce University, Konuralp Yerleşkesi, 81620 Düzce, Turkey. Email: suatsaridemir@duzce.edu.tr

abstract.p: In this article, artificial neural network has been used in order to predict the power (P) and torque (T) values obtained from a beta-type Stirling engine that uses air as working fluid. Experimental data have been obtained for different charge pressures and hot source temperatures using ZrO2-coated and uncoated displacers. The closest artificial neural network results to experimental torque and power values were obtained with double hidden layer 5–13–9–1 and 5–13–7–1 network architectures, respectively. The best prediction values were obtained by Levenberg–Marquardt learning algorithm. Correlation coefficient (R2) for the torque values were 0.998331 and 0.997231 for the training and test sets, respectively, while R2 value for power values were 0.998331 and 0.997231 for the training and test sets, respectively. R2 values show that the developed artificial neural network is an acceptable and powerful modelling technique in predicting the torque and power values of the beta-type Stirling engine.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Stirling engines are closed-cycle regenerative multipurpose engines which operate with the heat obtained from exogenous energy sources such as solid, gas and liquid. The material types of the engine parts used at manufacturing stage determine the maximum running temperature of these engines. The usage area of Stirling engines notably increases, because fossil-based fuels are expensive and their reserves are limited. Air, helium, nitrogen and hydrogen can also be used as working fluid in Stirling engines. In theory, these engines have higher thermal efficiency and low emissions.1 Theoretical thermo-dynamic analysis of Stirling engines shows that thermal efficiency is equal to Carnot cycle.2 After the first Stirling engine was designed and manufactured by Robert Stirling in 1816,3 different type Striling engines have been designed and manufactured, and their performances have been tested. Cinar and Karabulut3 designed and manufactured a gamma-type Stirling engine which had 276 cm3 sweep volume. In the tests conducted using air and helium, an electrical furnace was used as heat source. The tests were conducted with intervals of 700–1000 ℃ and 1–4.5 bars. In their tests conducted with helium and air at hot source temperature of 1000 ℃, maximum engine power was obtained as 128.3 W at charge pressure of 4 bars and as 58 W at charge pressure of 3 bars, respectively. In another study conducted by Batmaz and Ustun,2 tests of a V-type Stirling engine were conducted with interval of hot source temperatures of 650–1000 ℃. In tests conducted using helium as working fluid, charge pressure was taken between atmospheric pressure and 2 bars for each temperature. Maximum power obtained was 118 W at 950 ℃ and 1 bar charge pressure. Cinar et al.4 manufactured and tested a beta-type Stirling engine, which had a total sweep volume of 192 cm3. In tests at atmospheric pressure, it was observed that the speed, torque and engine power increased with increasing hot source temperature. Maximum power obtained was 5.98 W at hot source temperature of 1000 ℃ and 208 r/min. In their study, it was stated that the performance of the engine could be improved, when the working fluids such as hydrogen and helium, which have high thermal conductivity were used. Sripakagorn and Srikam5 manufactured a beta-type Stirling engine with a total sweep volume of 165 cm3 and carried out its performance tests. The engine performance was tested for different charge pressures and hot source temperatures. Maximum engine power was obtained as 3.8 W at atmospheric pressure, 350 ℃ and 205 r/min, whereas it was obtained as 95.4 W at charge pressure of 7 bars, 500 ℃ and 360 r/min. In the literature studies, it can be seen that engine performance increased in direct proportion to the hot source temperature. For this reason, thermal losses have significant impact on the engine performance.

In recent years, researchers have used different analysis and modelling techniques such as finite elements, genetic algorithm, fuzzy logic and artificial neural networks (ANNs) to reduce the numbers of expensive, complicated and time-consuming tests.6–9 ANN which is one of the most used techniques was developed based on the working principle of the human brain. ANN successfully used in computer, medicine, economy and military applications, is also widely used in automotive engineering.10–15 Shivakumar et al.16 used ANN in modelling of the compression-ignition engine which operated with a bio-diesel fuel made of waste cooking oil. ANN results showed that the predicted engine performance values and exhaust emission values were in good agreement with test results. Yusaf et al.17 performed a study that included both experimental and ANN approaches to determine the effects of usage of raw palm oil as fuel on engine performance and emissions in a diesel engine. As a result, R2 values for power, specific fuel consumption, NOx, CO, O2 and temperature values were calculated as 0.96, 0.823, 0.933, 0.939, 0.936 and 0.915, respectively. Oguz et al.18 carried out a study using ANN to model performance values of a diesel engine operated with different bio-fuels. With the ANN model, they predicted the power, moment, consumption per hour and specific fuel consumption. As a result, it was found that the correlation coefficients for all output parameters are very close to 1 (p = 0.9994 and p > 0.05). In addition to these studies, there are many studies conducted on the prediction of engine performance and exhaust emissions in the literature.19–21 Lack of a study on predicting Stirling engine performance using ANN in the literature clearly reveals the importance of this study.

In this study, an ANN model was developed for predicting the performance values of a beta-type Stirling engine. A number of experiments were performed to obtain experimental data using coated and uncoated displacers at different engine charge pressures, hot source temperatures, compression ratios and engine speeds. Engine performance values (torque and power) were predicted by the developed ANN model. With the conducted study, it became clear that ANN was a powerful modelling technique for the prediction of performance values in Stirling engines.

sec.title: Engine construction
sec.p:
A cross-sectional and photographic view of the beta-type Stirling engine are given in Figures 1 and 2. The technical specifications of the engine are given in Table 1. As can be seen in Figure 1, power piston and displacer move on the same axis. Power piston is made of nodular cast steel. After the piston was cast and roughly turned at lathe, it was ground at 0.01 mm accuracy on grinding machine tools and polished. Power piston rings were made of Teflon material, which could resist to friction and 300 ℃ temperature. Displacer was made of chromium–nickel steel as two copies. Taking into consideration the displacer and power piston connecting rods, static balancing was performed after manufacturing. With plasma spraying method, one of the pistons was coated with ZrO2 coating material which has lower thermal conductivity, at 0.3 mm thickness. The outer diameter of coated piston was machined as small 0.6 mm as normal diameter. Thus, diameter difference between coated and uncoated pistons was eliminated. Power piston was ground at crank grinding machine tool and its cylinder was accurately honned at honning machine tool. A running clearance of 0.03 mm was provided between power piston and cylinder. Connecting rod of the displacer and connecting rod of power piston were also mounted on ball bearings for decreasing friction. The engine output shaft was mounted on journal bearings which were made of bronze, and impermeability was provided with sealing rings. The engine which could resist to 8.5 bars charge pressure was manufactured as impermeable. O’ring seals were used to ensure impermeability at the joint sections of engine block and parts. The engine crank shaft was made of AISI D3 steel as multipartite and mounted on ball bearings. Figure 1.
Schematic illustration of the test engine.
Figure 2.
The prototype Stirling engine.
Table 1.
Technical specifications of the test engine.
Parameters Specification
Engine type Beta
Power piston Bore × stroke for 1.4 Cr (mm) 54 × 34
Bore × stroke for 1.8 Cr (mm) 54 × 60
Swept volume for 1.4 Cr (cm3) 74.22
Swept volume for 1.8 Cr (cm3) 130.627
Bore × stroke (mm) 54 × 60
Swept volume (cm3) 137.41
Working fluid Air
Cooling system Water cooled
Compression ratio 1.4:1–1.8:1
Maximum engine power 24.80 W (at 320 r/min)

sec.title: Experimental setup and results
sec.p:
The engine was tested with the test mechanism shown in Figure 3. Prony brake dynamometer and digital scales were used in torque measurement along with 1 r/min-accurate digital tachometer. An electrical furnace, which has heating capacity between 0 ℃ and 1200 ℃ and has 1 ℃ accuracy, was used as heat source. The engine was cooled with city water. The control of charge pressure was ensured with a manometer. Air was used as the working fluid. Figure 3.
Schematic view of the test equipment.

As shown in Figure 4(a), maximum power values are 5.73 and 4.28 W for coated and uncoated displacers at atmospheric pressure (1 bar), hot source temperature of 800 ℃ and compression ratio of 1.4:1, respectively. Maximum torque values become 0.26 and 0.19 Nm for coated and uncoated displacers at the same operating conditions, respectively (Figure 4(b)). As shown in Figure 5(a) and (b), maximum power values become 5.11 and 3.76 W, while maximum torque values for coated and uncoated displacers are 0.22 and 0.18 Nm at compression ratio of 1.8:1. The power and torque values increased up to charge pressure of 2.5–3 bars and then slightly decreased depending on charge pressure at both compression ratios. The power and torque values also increased with increasing hot source temperature at compression ratios of both 1.4:1 and 1.8:1. Figure 4.
Variations of (a) maximum power and (b) maximum torque values versus the charge pressure for compression ratio of 1.4:1.
Figure 5.
Variations of (a) maximum power and (b) maximum torque values versus the charge pressure for compression ratio of 1.8:1.

At lower charge pressures, due to the lack of sufficient fluid in the system, maximum pressure could not be obtained. For the engine, sufficient amount of fluid ensured the best working conditions at charge pressures of 3–3.5 bars for both compression ratios and different hot source temperatures. Since the charge pressure needed for operating the engine is provided from crank case, a counter-pressure, which decelerates the speed of piston occurrs. For this reason, the engine power reduced with the impact of counter-pressure at 4 bars level. Maximum power was obtained as 24.80 W at compression ratio of 1.4:1 and charge pressure of 3.5 bars, while it became 23.75 W at charge pressure of 3 bars and compression ratio of 1.8:1.

The ZrO2-coated displacer decreases the heat loss from hot area to cold area because of its lower thermal conductivity. For this reason, the power values obtained by coated piston were higher than ones obtained by uncoated piston at all test stages.

The engine power and torque values depending on the engine speed for both coated and uncoated displacers are shown in Figure 6 at hot source temperatures of 800 ℃ (Figure 6(a)), 900 ℃ (Figure 6(b)), 1000 ℃ (Figure 6(c)) and compression ratio of 1.4:1. As shown in Figure 6(b) and (c), maximum power values become 24.8 and 16.67 W, while maximum torque values for coated and uncoated displacers are 0.74 and 0.53 Nm at compression ratio of 1.4:1. It was observed that the maximum power and torque values were obtained at charge pressure of 3.5 bars, hot source temperature of 1000 ℃ and 300–350 r/min. Figure 6.
Variations of power and torque values at (a) 800 ℃, (b) 900 ℃ and (c) 1000 ℃ with engine speed for charge pressure of 1.4:1.

The engine power and torque values depending on the engine speed and compression ratio of 1.8:1 are shown in Figure 7 at hot source temperatures of 800 ℃ (Figure 7(a)), 900 ℃ (Figure 7(b)) and 1000 ℃ (Figure 7(c)). Similarly, the maximum power and torque values were obtained at 300–350 r/min and hot source temperature of 1000 ℃ with coated displacer. Figure 7.
Variations of power and torque values at (a) 800 ℃, (b) 900 ℃ and (c) 1000 ℃ with engine speed for charge pressure of 1.8:1.

As shown in Figures 6 and 7, the power and torque values are higher at low speed than at high speed. The hot source transferred more heat energy to working fluid at low speeds. Thus, the power and torque values were higher at low engine speeds. The negative effect of working fluid leakage terminated the increase in power and torque values. At high speeds, power and torque values reduced with insufficient heat transfer and increasing friction power. The change of the torque with engine speed is a typical characteristic of Stirling engines.22,23

Under testing conditions, a counter-pressure was smaller at compression ratio of 1.4:1 than compression ratio of 1.8:1. The counter-pressure reduced speed of the power piston and engine power, because the charge pressure was provided within engine crankcase. The stroke of power piston was 34 mm at compression ratio of 1.4:1, whereas it was 60 mm at compression ratio of 1.8:1. At compression ratio of 1.4:1, shorter stroke of power piston led to smaller friction resistance between cylinder and piston when compared to compression ratio of 1.8:1. For this reason, more power was obtained with compression ratio of 1.4:1. In addition, turning radii of connecting rod and ball bearing were 17 mm at compression ratio of 1.4:1, while the turning radii of them for 1.8:1 became 30 mm. As turning radius grew, the inertia force which affects the crank shaft of the engine increased. The generated inertia forces cannot be completely balanced with counter-weights; thus, vibrations increased and negatively affected the engine power.

sec.title: Design and application of ANN model
sec.p: ANNs are an information-processing system which was inspired by biological neural networks and which include some performance features comparable to biological neural networks.24 ANNs have various important features such as learning from the data, generalization, working with infinite number of variables, etc. The smallest units that form the basis of the operation of ANNs are called as artificial neural cells (neurons). The simplest artificial neural cells consist of inputs, weights, summation function, activation function and outputs. The summation function is a function which calculates the net input of a cell. Summation function used in this study is given in equation (1) (1)NETi=∑j=1 nwijxj+wbi where NETi is the weighted sum of the input to the ith processing element, i and j the processing elements, n the number of processing elements in the previous layer, wij the weights of the connections between ith and jth processing elements, xj the output of the jth processing element and wbi the weights of the biases between layers. Activation function provides a curvilinear match between input and output layers. In addition, it determines the output of the cell by processing net input to the cell. Selection of an appropriate activation function notably affects network performance. There are many ways to define the activation function, such as threshold function, step activation function, sigmoid function and hyperbolic tangent function. The selection of activation function depends on the neural network type to be designed. A sigmoid function is commonly used as the transfer function in the ANNs. Logistic transfer function of the ANN model in this study is given in equation (2) (2)f (NETi )=11+e-NETi

ANN architectures built for the prediction of torque and engine power in this study are provided in Figure 8. Figure 8.
ANN architectures with two hidden layer for torque and power of the Stirling engine.
ANN: artificial neural network.
Figure 9.
The performance of ANN for torque values.
ANN: artificial neural network.

In this study, back-propagation algorithm was used for prediction of the Stirling engine performance values. In addition, as a result of the conducted trials, the best results for prediction of power and torque values were obtained with the Levenberg–Marquardt learning algorithm which is frequently encountered in the literature.25,26 The network has five input parameters namely, hot source temperature (Hst), piston coating (Pc), compression ratio (Cr), charge pressure (Cp) and engine speed (N). Network architectures for torque and power were 5–13–9–1 and 5–13–7–1, respectively (Figure 8). Experimental data (608) for each input and output obtained as a result of the Stirling engine tests were prepared for the training and testing sets of ANN. In this article, training and testing set were created by taking as reference the 90%:10%27,28 ratio approximately. In this regard, 62 testing and 546 training data were randomly chosen from whole experimental data.

The data can be normalized in different ways in ANN applications, the normalization procedures widely used in the literature are between 0 and 129 and 1 and −130 values. The formula provided in equation (3) was used for the normalization of the outputs.31 The output values were normalized between 0.1 and 0.9 by taking equation (3) as reference (3)nvi=0.8× (vmin-vivmin-vmax )+0.1 where nvi is the normalization value, vmax the maximum value of the input/output data, vmin the minimum value of the input/output data and vi the ith value of the input/output data. Torque and power values predicted as a result of ANN training were compared to the values obtained from experimental study. Root mean square error (RMSE), R2 and mean error percentage (MEP) values were used for this comparison. RMSE, R2 and MEP are defined as follows (4)RMSE= ( (1p )∑j |tj-oj |2 )1/2
(5)MEP=∑j ( (tj-oj )/tj )×100p
(6)R2=1- (∑j (tj-oj )2∑j (oj )2 ) where t is the target value, o the output and p the number of samples. The parameter tj represents the predicted output from the neural network model for a given input while oj the desired output from the same input that was produced by set up. The performance of ANN for torque and power values is shown in Figures 9 and 10, respectively. In Figure 9, it can be clearly seen that the predicted testing and training data for torque values are very close to the experimental results. This case is also supported by the fact that the obtained R2 values are very close to 1. In the ANN model developed for the prediction of the torque of Stirling testing engine, RMSE values were calculated as 0.020163 and 0.013474 for testing and training data, respectively. MEP values for torque were found as 4.493131% and 3.626631% for testing and training data, respectively. In Figure 10, the performance of ANN power values is shown. Likewise, these figures show that the predicted results for both training data and testing sets are very close to the experimental results. In the developed ANN model, RMSE values were calculated as 0.021437 and 0.015583 for testing and training data, respectively. MEP values for torque were found as 4.73107% and 4.229458% for testing and training sets, respectively. It was observed that the ANN was significantly successful in prediction of torque and power values of a beta-type Stirling engine. Figure 10.
The performance of ANN for engine power.
ANN: artificial neural network.

Mathematical formulas belonging to the torque and power obtained using the ANN approach are given in equations (7) and (8). With these formulas, a new mathematical model which can calculate the performance values of a beta-type Stirling engine without needing any experimental work is introduced

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
In this study, an ANN model was developed using the experimental data obtained from the beta-type Stirling engine. The power and torque values obtained with Stirling engine under different operating conditions was predicted. The following conclusions were reached through experimental work and the ANN application:
The maximum engine power increased about 100% when ZrO2 was coated on the displacer and the engine was operated at hot source temperature of 900 ℃ and compression ratio of 1.4:1. This ratio became about hot source temperatures of 50% for 800 ℃ and 1000 ℃. (7)T=11+e-(10.2831×F1+83.088×F2+107.9811×F3-7.9382×F4-110.3017×F5+82.8976×F6-5.5299×F7+10.8946×F8-42.6294×F9-40.5273)
(8)P=11+e-(-12.9660×F1-154.8621×F2+3.4785×F3-21.1969×F4+33.4984×F5+150.2931×F6-26.8314×F7+14.9386)
Maximum power and torque values were obtained at hot source temperature of 1000 ℃, compression ratio of 1.4:1 and charge pressure levels of 3–3.5 bars.
R2 values obtained for both torque and power predicted with ANN were very close to 1.
MEP values for the Stirling engine were found in acceptable limits (±5%). They were calculated as below 4.5% and 4.8% for torque and power, respectively. These error values are notably satisfactory.

According to the obtained results, the ANN model developed for predicting the torque and power values of the beta-type Stirling engine gave correct and acceptable results. Therefore, instead of expensive, complicated and time-consuming experiments, it is highly recommended that the ANN can be used for predicting the performance of Stirling engines.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
